Situation1: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Expectation2: Live according to Christian moral values and ethics
Situation2: They encounter choices where Christian ethics become more relevant
Story:
I sat at my desk, headset snug against my ear, the script for our new service open in front of me. As a telemarketer, I was expected to handle every objection, to keep the conversation moving, and to close the sale. But today, the calls were different. Prospects kept asking detailed technical questions—questions the script only half-answered. My supervisor’s voice echoed in my mind: “Stick to the script, don’t get sidetracked, and never admit what you don’t know.”

But as a Christian, honesty was non-negotiable. I remembered Sunday’s sermon about truthfulness, about letting your “yes” be yes and your “no” be no. Each time a customer asked if the service could really do everything we claimed, I felt a knot tighten in my stomach. The script nudged me to gloss over the gaps, to redirect, to keep the sale alive. But my faith demanded transparency, even if it meant losing a commission. My finger hovered over the mute button, my heart pounding as I wrestled with what to say next.
